pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: I know we extensively discussed screw joints and how they require 2 axes. Now looking at the [joint visuals on GzWeb](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gzweb/pull-request/72/view-joints/diff), I realize that I made a visualization for only one of them on purpose and I'm not quite sure how we got to that...  Would it be the case here to make only one as well, or maybe attach a rotation marker to one of them...?
content.html: I know we extensively discussed screw joints and how they require 2 axes. Now looking at the joint visuals on GzWeb, I realize that I made a visualization for only one of them on purpose and I'm not quite sure how we got to that... Would it be the case here to make only one as well, or maybe attach a rotation marker to one of them...?

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: screw joints can translate and rotate, but they only have one degree of freedom. I would say they just have one axis.
content.html: screw joints can translate and rotate, but they only have one degree of freedom. I would say they just have one axis.

content.html: Oh yeah... It's a bit confusing that the model list displays 2 axes... By the way, the SDF documentation has no mention of screw but does have a piston.

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.html:
I think the treatment of the universal joint axes is not yet correct. From UniversalJoint.hh:

    /// Axis1 and axis2 are body-fixed, with axis1 attached to parent
    /// body and axis2 attached to child body.

We need to attach Axis1 to the parent body. Currently both are attached to the child body. For an example model, see cart_front_steer, which has universal joints at the front wheels. The vertical steering axis shouldn't rotate with the wheels as it rolls forwards or backwards.

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: Otherwise this is looking good to me.
content.html: Otherwise this is looking good to me.

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: Why are we setting the axis of rotation to yellow? We should probably keep the RGB <-> XYZ convention. The circle around the axis could be yellow.
content.html: Why are we setting the axis of rotation to yellow? We should probably keep the RGB <-> XYZ convention. The circle around the axis could be yellow.

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw:
I remember there was some discussions a while ago that to come up with visual representation that capture the case where main joint axis vector (specified by `<xyz>`) is not one of the unit x, y, or z axes of the joint frame. So we came up with using yellow to draw this axis. 

Most of the time it coincides with the joint frame's x, y, or z axis, in this case I hide the the one it overlaps with. If you think it's better we can revert to the original behavior and think of another way to visualize the joint axis vector.
content.html:
I remember there was some discussions a while ago that to come up with visual representation that capture the case where main joint axis vector (specified by <xyz>) is not one of the unit x, y, or z axes of the joint frame. So we came up with using yellow to draw this axis.

Most of the time it coincides with the joint frame's x, y, or z axis, in this case I hide the the one it overlaps with. If you think it's better we can revert to the original behavior and think of another way to visualize the joint axis vector.

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: Keeping red and green for the secondary axis can be confusing. How about yellow for the primary, and grey for the other two?
content.html: Keeping red and green for the secondary axis can be confusing. How about yellow for the primary, and grey for the other two?

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: True, it could be confusing to have one of the `RGB` missing... But I guess by making them grey we are losing a lot of information. How about some sort of mix, like keeping the arrow heads `RGB` and only change the arrow's body to yellow in case they overlap, or the other way around?
content.html: True, it could be confusing to have one of the RGB missing... But I guess by making them grey we are losing a lot of information. How about some sort of mix, like keeping the arrow heads RGB and only change the arrow's body to yellow in case they overlap, or the other way around?

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: ya I agree we could lose some information about the joint frame. The hybrid yellow and axis color is a good idea.
content.html: ya I agree we could lose some information about the joint frame. The hybrid yellow and axis color is a good idea.

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: Is there value of having both the RGB and Yellow arrows for the joint axis? I believe this is the current situation. Is the RGB suppose to represent the joint frame?
content.html: Is there value of having both the RGB and Yellow arrows for the joint axis? I believe this is the current situation. Is the RGB suppose to represent the joint frame?

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: The RGB represents the joint frame and I think there is some value in keeping it. Sometimes I find it useful when creating joints in sdf where I constantly switch in and out of Gazebo to see the RGB joint frame in order to get the right axis `<xyz>` values in sdf.
content.html: The RGB represents the joint frame and I think there is some value in keeping it. Sometimes I find it useful when creating joints in sdf where I constantly switch in and out of Gazebo to see the RGB joint frame in order to get the right axis <xyz> values in sdf.

content.raw:
Update as of edbaf45. 

- Joint visualization should be working properly for universal and revolute2 joints (see the left Cart Front Steer model below).

pullrequest.title: Fix joint visualization axis frame issue

content.raw: this is the case where it's gets a little bit complicated. For revolute2/universal: axis1 is attached to parent link and axis2 is attached to child link. I draw the RGB frame from axis2 only and check for overlap with axis2's `xyz` vector. The case in the screenshot above shows an overlap between axis2's RGB visual and axis1's `xyz`. I do not hide axis1 because as soon as the child link starts to rotate around axis2, the RGB 's blue axis will no longer overlap with axis1. Hope that makes sense
content.html: this is the case where it's gets a little bit complicated. For revolute2/universal: axis1 is attached to parent link and axis2 is attached to child link. I draw the RGB frame from axis2 only and check for overlap with axis2's xyz vector. The case in the screenshot above shows an overlap between axis2's RGB visual and axis1's xyz. I do not hide axis1 because as soon as the child link starts to rotate around axis2, the RGB 's blue axis will no longer overlap with axis1. Hope that makes sense
